column4: I would recommend this workshop to others
column5: Learning outcomes: I understand the overall architecture of the Alvis compute cluster
column6: Learning outcomes: I know some history and origins of current generative models with attention mechanism
column7: Learning outcomes: I understand the categories in which LLMs are released
column8: Learning outcomes: I know what to look for when selecting a language model for my use case
column9: Learning outcomes: I know the tools available on Alvis for LLM inference
column10: Learning outcomes: I can perform inference using LLM inference engine/server
column11: Learning outcomes: I understand the OpenAI API
column12: Learning outcomes: I know different ways to perform offline inference
column13: Learning outcomes: I know the general structure of neural networks
column14: Learning outcomes: I know why the Transformer architecture helped training LLMs
column15: Learning outcomes: I know the difference in needs of LLM training/fine-tuning/inference
column16: Learning outcomes: I know some tricks to reduce the computational and memory footprint of LLMs
column17: Learning outcomes: I understand some elements in LLM names
column18: Learning outcomes: I know common formats in which LLMs are saved on disk
column19: Learning outcomes: I know common datatypes relevant to LLMs
column20: Learning outcomes: I know common ways of performing quantization
column21: Learning outcomes: I know how to check compatibility between models and hardware
column22: General: Anything else you would like us to know?
exercises pace should be slower and better documented
Time for exercises too little. More time needed. More examples on the github repo as well please.
More time spent on worked examples, instead of lecture style sections. Easier to digest how things work in practice that way.

Today’s exercise felt extremely rushed, we were given only about five minutes to complete it, which was far too quick. For future sessions, it would be very helpful to allow more time so we can fully engage with the task.    Additionally, the explanation of the exercise was quite fast and somewhat ad-hoc, making it difficult to follow what was being done and why. Since it was the only hands-on part of the day, it would have been great to receive a clearer walkthrough and enough time to actually absorb the material.    I really hope that for the next exercises we can have a more structured explanation and more time to complete the tasks. This would make the hands-on portion much more valuable and easier to grasp.

The instructions for the practical exercises are very incomplete. The super simple stuff in the beginning is clear but the actually useful exercises on running interference have incomplete commands in the provided material. If you’re not familiar to this environment and get a little stuck, then there is no way to catch up because the commands for the next step is no longer available since it was only shown on the screen and not included in the slides.

The last two lectures were complicated, but I still have an unanswered question: given >20 "flavors" of the same LLM with different quantizations / Instruct / whatever, is there a method to choose which ONE FLAVOR I should use on Alvis, except by re-running my "typical task" for each of these flavors and manually examining them to score the performance?

Based on the workshop description I was expecting more hands-on sessions were the different concepts are actually practiced by the participants. In the inference session, the material about using vllm was poorly accessible and it was not clear what we were supposed to achieve. In the quantization session, I would have expected a more practical approach that shows me how I perform this and benchmark the result on my own. So far I don't think I have gained the expected practical skills for working with LLMs on the HPC system.
